Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative Trait Locus Editing for Crop Improvement
Award.AbstractNarration:
Milestone achievements in crop research now enable difficult challenges to be addressed rapidly and effectively using innovative approaches. These achievements include DNA sequences and measurements of traits relevant to productivity and quality for large numbers of varieties within individual crop species, powerful computational approaches and data management tools, increasingly detailed molecular understanding of plant biology including responses to the environment, and new methods to precisely test the function of particular DNA sequences. Building on these resources and tools, this project will address the longstanding challenge of identifying DNA sequences responsible for traits that vary in a quantitative way, called "quantitative trait loci" (QTL), and making them amenable for crop improvement. While QTL are key determinants of crop productivity, they have been exceedingly difficult to study, and very little is known about them. This project focuses on QTL for disease resistance, disease susceptibility, and tolerance to acid soils in the globally important crop species, rice. The project will isolate DNA sequences associated with high levels of these traits and test whether those sequences are responsible by moving them into rice varieties that show low trait levels and measuring the result. The project will improve understanding of crop resistance to stresses caused by pests and poor soil conditions and lead to improved crop productivity. More broadly, the project will establish effective ways to connect variation across individuals with the DNA sequences that cause that variation, which will be useful not only for plant research, but other life sciences, including medicine. The project will further benefit society by integrating its research objectives with educational activities and materials that will engage and inform the public and increase participation by members of underrepresented groups. These include a combined classroom and research experience program for small-college undergraduates, training workshops for plant biologists, multi-media educational resources to engage middle and high school students, and a project web site (www.ricediversity.org) for public access to project-related materials, publications, and data. Moreover, the project will foster the development of diverse junior personnel into independent scientists

Compilations of genomic and other genotypic as well as phenotypic and associated metadata for large numbers of rice, powerful informatics approaches and data management tools, the unprecedented ability to precisely edit plant genomes to probe gene function, and increasingly detailed molecular understanding of rice responses to biotic and abiotic stresses, together provide a foundation for this project. This project applies large-scale statistical genetics and genome editing technology to examine distinct QTL for disease resistance, disease susceptibility, and acid soil tolerance. Building on genomic and phenotypic data, computational methods, and infrastructure generated under previous NSF awards and elsewhere, including the recently released genome sequences of 3,000 rice accessions, the project will connect genotype to phenotype for each trait, using genome editing to functionally evaluate isolated genetic polymorphism in new genetic backgrounds. Co-variation will also be examined for each trait to test for genetic background effects on allele viability, and in the case of disease susceptibility and resistance, allelic variation in pathogen-targeted genes will be queried for evidence of purifying or positive selection. Findings will be used to expand the tools and the collection of genotypic and phenotypic data associated with the project, and tailor these resources for the community, while improving understanding of and the ability to enhance plant resistance to biotic and abiotic stresses. Under the outreach objectives of the project, the combined classroom and research experience program for small-college undergraduates will integrate computational and molecular biology aspects of the proposed research and include summer internships in the research laboratories at Cornell. The training workshops will focus specifically on genome editing for plant biologists, especially those from underserved and underrepresented groups; the multimedia educational resources will include stories, podcasts, and interactive web modules and will be distributed through major media outlets; the project web site (www.ricediversity.org) for scientists, the general public, and educators will provide access to project-related materials, protocols, publications, and data (data will be released on or before publication of analytical results). Finally, the development of diverse junior personnel into capable, creative, and collaborative independent scientists will be fostered by a multi-institutional, cross-disciplinary research environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project served the long-term goal of sustainable production of food, feed, and fiber for a growing world population in the face of climate change and reductions in arable land.  The project aimed to improve tools for specific spelling changes in plant genomes and to assess the feasibility of ?editing? DNA sequences for traits like disease resistance and drought tolerance found in some varieties into other, high-quality or high-yielding varieties. Often, such traits vary quantitatively, and their genetic determinants, called ?quantitative trait loci? (QTL), can be difficult to identify and to mobilize by conventional breeding. This project focused on QTL for disease resistance, disease susceptibility, and tolerance to acid soils in rice, a global staple and a useful model for cereal biology.

The project yielded 25 peer-reviewed publications and numerous presentations, documenting

  • New tools and techniques for editing plant genomes, including viral delivery, non-GMO approaches, tissue-culture-free methods, and a user-friendly set of reagents for different plant species.
  • New uses of plant genome editing, including the study of sequences that control gene expression for disease resistance and susceptibility, and the biochemical tagging of plant proteins to determine their location and interactors within the cell.
  • Better understanding of TAL effectors, proteins used in genome editing that recognize and bind specific DNA sequences by virtue of a series of repeated structural elements, each of which interacts consecutively with a single DNA base. This new understanding includes the optimal repeat number for maximum specificity, and the discovery that TAL effectors in their native context, as plant gene activators, function bi-directionally on DNA.
  • New databases and search tools to facilitate research in plant genomics and plant disease, including ?daTALbase,? providing comprehensive data on TAL effectors and the plant genomic sequences they target, and ?MontyDB,? (publication pending) an integrated resource for mining a comprehensive collection of genomic diversity data for Asian and African rice. 
  • Improved knowledge of rice genes controlling disease resistance, susceptibility, and nutrient transport, including 1) the discovery of ?cis-regulatory modules? (CRMs), sequences that govern expression of defense response genes, 2) the characterization of genes governing susceptibility to bacterial blight and bacterial leaf streak, and 3) identification of gene sequence variation that controls phosphorous distribution, in particular the content in seeds of the anti-nutrient phytate (publication pending).

These scientific contributions advanced the field of plant genome editing, especially as it relates to QTL. This can be expected to have broad positive impacts on fundamental and translational plant biology, empowering plant breeding and leading to improved crop productivity.

A major objective beyond scientific discovery was integrating research and education to engage and inform the public and increase participation by members of underrepresented groups. Specific objectives included a classroom and research experience program for undergraduates, plant genome editing workshops for junior scientists, multi-media educational resources to engage middle and high school students, a project website for access to materials, publications, and data, and facilitating the development of diverse junior personnel into independent scientists through participation in the project.

  • Through the undergraduate program, conducted at a small college serving rural, first-generation students (Doane University), with summer internships at Cornell, the project provided mentored research experience for 33 participants as well as new content in plant genomics and plant genome editing for 2 new courses that integrate computer science and biology.
  • Genome editing workshops held in 2016 and 2018 at University of Minnesota and Colorado State University provided lectures and training for 27 and 67 attendees, respectively.
  • Additionally, knowledge and tools developed through the project formed the basis for a genome editing module conducted by project participants at the ?Rice: Research to Production? workshop held at the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines, yearly serving ~35 participants (~1/3 U.S.), and for a new workshop, ?Advanced Crop Genetics? held at AfricaRice in Senegal in 2019, training 23 participants (11 U.S.).
  • The project continues to enhance middle and high school learning in plant biology, including breeding, genetics, and genome editing, through interactive web modules with teacher guide and student worksheets published on the ?Plants, Genes, and People? website. This resource is widely used and easily located: from August 1, 2020 through July 7, 2021, the site hosted 6734 sessions by 5775 users, 40% U.S. and the remainder from over 10 other countries. Seventy-two percent of the visits were from a search engine referral, twenty-one percent were direct access, and the remainder were referrals from other websites.
  • The project website provided access to knowledge, skills, and reagents developed.
  • The project provided research experience and training in plant genomics, genome editing, molecular biology, and computational biology, in an internationally collaborative context, for 4 graduate students, and 7 postdoctoral researchers.

These activities and resources, alongside the scientific publications and presentations, have increased public awareness and understanding of plant genomics and genetics, broadened participation, and strengthened the agricultural research workforce.
